title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) — On a night where baskets were a premium and defenses reigned, the Atlanta Hawks needed a historic performance to survive. They got one from a relentless force named Dikembe Mutombo.

In a bruising 89-87 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics, the stat sheet told a familiar story of gritty defense and offensive struggle. But one line defied belief: Mutombo’s 31 rebounds. In an era of low-scoring, physical basketball, the 7-foot-2 center authored a performance for the ages, single-handedly controlling the painted area and anchoring the Hawks' desperate comeback.

The Sonics, led by Vinny Del Negro’s 24 points and Hersey Hawkins’ 21, seemed poised to escape with a road win. But Mutombo’s sheer will kept Atlanta alive. Each of his 31 rebounds—a staggering 16 on the offensive glass—chipped away at Seattle’s resolve, creating second chances and extinguishing their possessions. His final stat line was a monument to dominance: 14 points, 31 rebounds, and 4 blocks.

With the game on the line, it was Mookie Blaylock who delivered the final blow, his 19 points culminating in the game-winning basket. But this night belonged to the man in the middle. Mutombo’s gargantuan effort on the boards was the foundation upon which this narrow victory was built, a reminder that sometimes, history is written not with flashy points, but with raw, indomitable power.
